hobby.message: Political literature still whispering to you?
Still flying like no one's watching?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Yeah, holding together.
Been keeping busy with photography, nothing fancy.
Things have changed lately but I make do.
Had to switch up my routes after the neighborhood split off.
Not falling apart. Thanks for asking.
I shoot street photos, old school film style.
Makes it trickier when places suddenly lock down.
Last week’s breakaway slowed things, but the camera still comes with me.
Just need the right light, you know?
I'm hanging in there, appreciate it.
Been out snapping street shots again, 35mm film, not digital.
That split neighborhood? Interesting faces, real energy—felt different.
Used to hide the camera, but lately folks want to be seen.
Film’s getting hard to find with all this chaos, though.
Still, I think the real stories are on those rolls.
Could be worse, honestly. Thanks for checking in.
You know I do street photography—film only, nothing that can be wiped.
Since that ‘free zone’ broke off, I risk more for good shots.
Last Sunday, people lined up for portraits—wanted proof they were outside the system.
Used to feel hunted. Now, sometimes, it feels electric, almost hopeful.
Maybe I’m documenting a whole new city out there.
Just hope I get to keep showing it.
Appreciate it, Alex, really.
Analog street photography is my thing—film, real prints, none of that digital fog.
Growing up, my father policed the BCI—everything was surveillance, nothing was honest.
I started shooting after curfews, always dodging street cams.
After I supported that breakaway district, things changed fast—now folks hand me stories on the street.
Documented their first meeting—people trusted the lens more than the system.
Keeping the negatives hidden is a daily game now, but I need to.
Feels like this is the first time my hobby actually matters—to someone besides me.
hobby_answer: That's right. Analog shots, nothing fancy.
No filters, no metadata. Just the image.
Let’s just say the recent free zones make street work less predictable.
People get suspicious fast.
Can never be too careful now.
Yeah, analog only. No digital trail, ever.
Film’s hard to get these days with BCI on alert.
Crowds change after that neighborhood broke away—some duck the lens, some don’t care.
Snapped a few shots during last week’s market. Quick and quiet.
Used to get questions, now I get stares.
Tension’s everywhere.
Analog shots never lie, that’s for sure.
I hunt for unfiltered moments—real expressions, not the staged state stuff.
Since those BCI leaks and the breakaway, the city’s faces changed overnight.
Kids in the free zone ham it up—they’re proud, loud, almost celebratory.
Others, near the border, still watch for cams on every corner.
Film runs out faster now—everyone wants their piece of the real story.
I just try to keep pace.
Absolutely, analog’s the only way left to see what’s real now.
I grew up with digital, but the state edits everything—they can’t edit film in my pocket.
Last weekend, in the breakaway market, people lined up for portraits holding fake scorecards.
There’s this sense of relief… nobody’s shadowboxing with the system.
It’s addictive, honest chaos—sometimes I burn three rolls an hour just chasing it.
The BCI backfiring pushed even shy people to open up to the lens.
It’s not just me—everyone’s desperate to be seen now, like they exist again.
Even the light feels different in those streets.
Analog’s my protest and my sanity—real faces, real imperfections. It’s how I remember who we are.
Back before Halden fell, film was for nostalgia. Now it’s survival—truth stashed away from system reach.
Since I got flagged, digital’s suicide. Film, I can hide. I never trust my phone.
When the free zone cut BCI ties, people looked me in the eye, not at some sensor.
Older folks brought out family photos—asked if tomorrow I’d return for stories behind their smiles.
That old man with the cardboard zero? He hugged me, said he finally felt seen.
Every new roll I get is a lifeline—sometimes I barter with coffee just to score one.
Even sharing contact prints is risky now. But those moments I catch—they’re alive, nobody can erase them.
Funny, city’s never been more broken, but behind the lens, people finally look whole.
